questions.question: In the PLAN-T architecture introduced in Lesson 1, what does the 'L' specifically represent regarding the treatment hierarchy?
options: Lipid Profile Management and Cardiovascular Health
questions.explanation: The 'L' stands for Leveling-Up, which focuses on Phase 2: Nutrient Optimization and ensuring all micro- and macronutrient needs are met through strategic food choices and supplementation.

questions.question: During Phase 1 (Preparation & Planning), a 'Kitchen Audit' is performed. According to the protocol, what is the primary purpose of the 'Transition Zone' in a client's pantry?
options: To store highly processed 'cheat' foods for emergency use
To isolate common allergens like gluten and soy
To house temporary whole-food substitutes that bridge the gap between SAD and WFPB
To store bulk grains and legumes that require soaking
questions.explanation: The Transition Zone is a strategic area for whole-food substitutes (like lentil pasta or cashew cream) that help clients transition from the Standard American Diet (SAD) to a Whole Food Plant-Based (WFPB) lifestyle.

questions.question: In Phase 2 (Nutrient Optimization), the course cites a meta-analysis regarding Vitamin B12. What is the recommended 'Maintenance Dose' for sublingual Cyanocobalamin for an adult with no absorption issues?
questions.explanation: For maintenance in healthy adults on a plant-based diet, 250 mcg daily or a larger weekly dose of 2,500 mcg is the standard evidence-based recommendation for Cyanocobalamin.

questions.question: Phase 3 (Anti-Inflammatory Interventions) focuses on reducing high-sensitivity C-Reactive Protein (hs-CRP). Which specific dietary addition has been shown to reduce hs-CRP by up to 30% in clinical trials?
options: Daily consumption of 1-2 ounces of raw walnuts
Replacing all fruit with green leafy vegetables
Consuming 50g of isolated soy protein daily
questions.explanation: Walnuts are rich in Alpha-Linolenic Acid (ALA) and polyphenols; clinical data shows consistent reductions in inflammatory markers like hs-CRP when included daily.

questions.question: When implementing Phase 4 (Microbiome Reconstruction), what is the 'Diversity Target' for unique plant species per week to maximize microbial richness?
questions.explanation: The American Gut Project found that individuals who consume 30+ different types of plant foods per week have significantly more diverse microbiomes than those who consume fewer than 10.

questions.question: In Phase 5 (Behavioral Integration), the coach uses 'Implementation Intentions.' Which of the following is the correct format for this strategy?
options: 'I will try to eat more vegetables this week.'
'If I am at a restaurant, then I will order a side salad before my main course.'
'I want to lose 10 pounds in 3 months.'
'I will stop eating processed sugar starting tomorrow.'
questions.explanation: Implementation Intentions follow an 'If-Then' format, linking a situational cue with a specific behavior, which significantly increases the likelihood of habit formation.

questions.question: During the 'Monitoring and Evaluation' phase (Lesson 7), how often should a coach typically recommend re-testing a client's serum Ferritin levels if they are addressing a known deficiency?
questions.explanation: Iron stores (Ferritin) change slowly; re-testing every 3-6 months allows enough time for dietary and supplementation changes to manifest in blood work without unnecessary testing.

questions.question: In Lesson 8 (Professional Documentation), where should a coach record a client's reported 'feeling of bloating after meals' within a SOAP note?
questions.explanation: The Subjective section contains information reported by the client, including their symptoms, feelings, and self-reported adherence.

questions.question: Case Study: Client 'David' presents with high LDL cholesterol (160 mg/dL) and low fiber intake (12g/day). According to Phase 3 and 4 protocols, what is the most effective intervention for David?
options: Titrating fiber up to 40g/day using viscous fibers like oats and beans
Eliminating all fats, including avocados and nuts
Increasing protein intake to 2.0g/kg of body weight
questions.explanation: Viscous (soluble) fiber binds to bile acids in the gut, forcing the liver to use blood cholesterol to make more, effectively lowering LDL. Titration is necessary to avoid GI distress (Phase 4).

questions.question: According to the Module 21 guidelines, what is the 'Golden Rule' of Plan Iteration when a client is not seeing results?
options: Change all variables at once to jumpstart the metabolism
Wait at least 12 months before making any changes
Change only one variable at a time and monitor for 2-4 weeks
Switch the client back to an omnivorous diet immediately
questions.explanation: To accurately identify what is or isn't working, coaches should isolate variables by changing one thing at a time and allowing a sufficient observation period (usually 2-4 weeks).
